Description: Egyptian terracotta antefix corner. An antefixal ornament from the corner of a structure, with simplified acanthus decoration. It is hand-modelled, with applied leaves, the edges of which are defined by incised grooves. Rough holes are pierced almost right through, below the arch of the lowest leaves on each side, and the stumps of inserted clay stems survive in both. Orange-brown Nile silt with a grey core, with common gold mica and white inclusions.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Fabric similar to Naukratis Nile silt kiln products. It is unlikely, but not impossible that it was brought from elsewhere in the Nile basin or delta.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (C920)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (AC.20) (Phase 3)
Condition: The two lower corners on each side are broken away, and three of the applied leaves are lost, leaving only their stems and the incisions that delineated them. A modern hole is bored underneath to fix the object to a stand.
Acquisition name: Donated by: British School at Athens
